awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Secure Two Factor Authentication with Wearable Hardware Key using Human Body as a Wire
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to improve the security of a digital footprint by making a “hardware key” for two-factor authentication wearable. Breaches due to weak or stolen credentials is a major problem today, and phishing attacks and identity theft result in loss of assets for millions of users and organizations.  By increasing physical security and solving the problem of low compliance of two-factor authentication, digital security can be vastly improved. The proposed technology has the potential to resolve the current issues with two-factor authentication and greatly lower risks for breaches. 

This I-Corps project aims to evaluate the commercialization potential of technology that uses the body as a wire, and in this proposal it will be applied to the case of secure authentication. Prior work has shown that the proposed technology enables physical security by preventing hackers from snooping the signal, unlike wireless technologies such as Bluetooth. Prior research has established that it is possible to develop low-loss communication at low frequencies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goals for the project I-Corps: Secure Two Factor Authentication with Wearable Hardware Key using Human Body as a Wire remains the same as any I-Corps team – as outlined by the National Science Foundation I-Corps Website – in order to take NSF research lineage and to commercialize to the general public for greater impact – the goal is to create successful technology translation. Throughout the I-Corps project cohort the BDYWR team had meetings with over a hundred IAM and security professionals that gave BDYWR a market validation. In addition, we continue to have meetings and attend conferences in the areas of medical devices, AR/VR metaverse and defense individuals over the course of the next two years. We brought on 2 other team members that are dedicated to furthering our commercialization efforts. The BDYWR team had discovered other segments that our technology can apply, specifically in the exciting AR/VR segment and motion tracking verticals where the existence of low power communication wearables can enable practical devices that is not possible with today's wireless communication over the course of the next two years BDYWR and those working closely with BDYWR had many meetings and conference attendances that lead to further leads and learning about the market. Some of these leads include using this technology for defense applications.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Shreyas Sen
